::: {.callout-important}
## The Big Idea

**Pretty pictures → measurements → models → inferences.** Astronomy is inference under extreme constraints: we usually can’t touch, sample, or experiment on the objects we study. We measure signals—most often light—and we use physics to translate those measurements into claims about physical reality.
:::

::: {.callout-important}
## Before and After This Reading

**Before:** “Pretty pictures” feel like decoration, and astronomy feels like a list of facts.

**After:** You can point at a figure and say what was **measured**, what was **inferred**, and what physics (plus assumptions) makes that inference legitimate.
:::

## Spoiler Alerts: This Is a Trailer, Not a Dictionary

::: {.callout-note}
## Roadmap

In this section, we’ll:

1. Say what Day 1 is doing (big conclusions first, details later)
2. Define the three words that run the whole course: observable, model, inference
3. Practice the “What you see → What physics tells us” habit
:::

{{< fig milky-way-panoramic >}}

On Day 1, I’m going to show you conclusions before you can fully justify them. That’s not a trick—it’s a trailer. The goal is that you start recognizing the *kind* of reasoning astronomers do: we make claims that are constrained by measurement and checkable by physics.

If you remember one sentence from this course, make it this one:

**Pretty pictures → measurements → models → inferences.**

Everything else is a detail of how to do that honestly.

:::{.column-margin}
**Observable:** a quantity we can measure directly with a detector (counts, brightness, position, wavelength).

**Model:** a rule (often an equation + assumptions) that connects observables to physical claims.

**Inference:** a physical property we conclude using a model (temperature, composition, mass, age, …).
:::

Here’s the habit we’ll practice all semester:

**What you see → What physics tells us.**

That “arrow” is where the work happens. Physics makes some stories possible and others impossible. Math makes assumptions explicit and checkable.

::: {.callout-tip}

## Spoiler Reel: Big Conclusions, Small Method

::: {.callout-note}
## Roadmap

In this section, we’ll:

1. Use the same three questions on multiple examples
2. See why wavelength is an information choice (not a decoration choice)
3. Practice separating measurement words from inference words
:::

Here is the rule we will use again and again:

1. **What do we measure?**
2. **What do we infer?**
3. **What physics makes that inference legal?**

:::{.column-margin}
**Wavelength \(\lambda\):** the “size” of a light wave; it determines which band you’re observing (radio, infrared, visible, …).

**Spectrum:** brightness as a function of wavelength; a physics fingerprint, not just “color.”
:::

### Example A: A nebula in visible light

{{< fig l1-rubin-first-light >}}

**What we measure:** patterns of brightness and color in a particular band of light.  
**What we infer:** hot gas, cooler dust, and specific atoms/ions contributing to the light.  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** atoms emit and absorb at specific wavelengths, and dust interacts with light in wavelength-dependent ways.

### Example B: “How far is it?” (why distance is a whole unit of the course)

{{< fig l1-distance-ladder >}}

**What we measure:** angles (parallax) nearby; apparent brightnesses of certain calibrator objects farther away.  
**What we infer:** distances across huge ranges.  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** geometry for nearby objects, plus physical relationships that allow calibrated brightness-based distance estimates farther out.

### Example C: The periodic table as a fossil record

{{< fig l1-origin-elements >}}

**What we measure:** element fingerprints in spectra and element abundances in different environments.  
**What we infer:** that different cosmic environments made different elements.  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** nuclear reaction pathways depend on physical conditions and leave observable chemical signatures.

### Example D: Splitting light into wavelengths

{{< fig l1-prism-dispersion >}}

**What we measure:** “white” light separated into components by wavelength.  
**What we infer:** light is information across many wavelengths at once.  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** dispersion and diffraction separate wavelengths, letting us measure them instead of guessing.

### Example E: Same galaxy, different physics

{{< fig l1-m51-optical-vs-radio >}}

**What we measure:** brightness maps at two different wavelength bands.  
**What we infer:** different components—stars, dust, gas—can dominate in different bands.  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** emission and absorption depend on wavelength; different processes “light up” different bands.

### Example F: Dust is not a wall (it’s wavelength-dependent)

{{< fig l1-pillars-optical-vs-ir >}}

**What we measure:** one band looks obscured; another reveals hidden structure.  
**What we infer:** dust blocks some wavelengths much more than others, so changing wavelength changes what you can see.  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** light–matter interactions are wavelength-dependent.

### Example G: One object, many emission mechanisms

{{< fig l1-crab-multiwavelength >}}

**What we measure:** the same sky position looks different in different bands.  
**What we infer:** multiple physical components co-exist (different temperatures, particle energies, magnetic fields, etc.).  
**What physics makes that inference legal:** different emission mechanisms dominate at different wavelengths.

::: {.callout-tip}

## The Decoder Ring: From Signals to Claims

::: {.callout-note}
## Roadmap

In this section, we’ll:

1. Name the inference workflow explicitly
2. List what we actually measure most of the time
3. Make “good reasoning” concrete (so you can practice it)
:::

When I say “astronomy is inference,” I mean a workflow like this:

**Signal → Measurement → Model → Inference → Prediction → Test**

Models sit in the middle. A model is not a vibe. It’s a rule that makes predictions and comes with assumptions. Those assumptions are the conditions under which the model is allowed to speak.

Across this course, our observables are surprisingly repetitive:

- **Brightness information** (counts/flux), often as a function of wavelength
- **Position and motion** on the sky
- **Timing** (variability)

From those, we infer physical properties—distance, luminosity, temperature, composition, radius, velocity, mass, age—by chaining models together.

::: {.quiz}
Which of the following is an **inference** rather than a direct measurement?

- [ ] A spectrum (brightness vs wavelength)
- [ ] A sky position
- [x] A temperature estimate
- [ ] A brightness measurement in a filter
:::

## Wavelength as an Information Choice (Not a Chart to Memorize)

::: {.callout-note}
## Roadmap

In this section, we’ll:

1. Treat the electromagnetic spectrum as a menu of “information channels”
2. Connect “different bands” to “different physics”
3. Preview why units and scaling matter next class
:::

{{< fig jwst-em-spectrum >}}

You do not need to memorize a spectrum chart on Day 1. What you do need is the direction of the idea:

- Different wavelength bands reveal different physical components.
- The same object can look like multiple “objects” if you change wavelength.
- That difference is *information*, not contradiction.

This is why “color” in astronomy is not decoration. It’s data.

## Lookback Time: Light Takes Time

::: {.callout-note}
## Roadmap

In this section, we’ll:

1. Introduce lookback time as a consequence of finite light speed
2. Do a dimensional-analysis (units) sanity check
3. Use a simple scaling inference: farther → older light
:::

One of the most important Day 1 ideas is that astronomy is a “lookback time” science: when we observe light from far away, we’re observing light that left the source earlier.

The simplest model for that is:

{{< include ../../../_includes/equations/lookback-time.qmd >}}
{{< eqrefcard lookback-time >}}

### Sanity check: do the units work?

Distance \(d\) has units of meters (m). Speed \(c\) has units of meters per second (m/s). So:

\[
[t] = \frac{[d]}{[c]} = \frac{\mathrm{m}}{\mathrm{m/s}} = \mathrm{s}
\]

The units force the story: dividing a distance by a speed gives a time.

::: {.callout-tip}
## Quick Check 3: Scaling with distance

If the distance to an object is 5× larger, what happens to the light travel time in this simplified model?

::: {.callout-note collapse="true"}
## Solution

It becomes 5× larger. In this model, \(t \propto d\).
:::
:::

## How to Succeed in ASTR 201 (Without Guessing)

::: {.callout-note}
## Roadmap

In this section, we’ll:

1. Translate “being good at astronomy” into concrete habits
2. Connect those habits to the course structure
3. Point you to the official policies (so we don’t reinvent them here)
:::

This course is not a memorization contest. It’s training in *scientific inference*: making claims that are checkable.

In practice, that means you will repeatedly do three things:

1. **Separate observation from inference.** (“What did we measure?”)
2. **Make assumptions visible.** (“Under what conditions is this model valid?”)
3. **Sanity-check everything.** (units, limiting cases, scaling)

The course logistics are built to reward those habits. For the official policy language and due dates, use:

- [Syllabus](/course-info/syllabus.qmd)
- [Why ASTR 201 is Different](/course-info/why-astr201-is-different.qmd)

Two concrete logistics that matter right away (and are easy to forget):

- Homework is due **Mon 11:59 pm**.
- The follow-up “grade memo” is due **Wed 11:59 pm** (this is where you practice diagnosing your own reasoning—not just your final answers).

Next class is “Math Boot Camp,” where we’ll practice units, scaling, and the sanity-check habits that make the rest of the course feel doable.
